questions.prompt: In BG 10.1, what does Krishna offer to reveal to Arjuna?
choices: Knowledge of worldly success and political influence
Mystical powers through material manipulation and discipline
My divine opulences and supreme position
Military strategies for winning the imminent battle
questions.feedback: Krishna offers to speak further confidential knowledge because Arjuna is His dear friend. He will reveal His divine opulences and supreme position - knowledge that brings supreme benefit. The principle: Krishna reveals Himself progressively to devoted souls. This confidential teaching shows how to recognize Krishna's presence throughout creation, establishing relationship between the infinite and finite through His manifestations.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 10.2, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn about regarding understanding Krishna?
choices: That demigods and great sages possess complete knowledge of Krishna's nature
That sensory experience combined with logic reveals Krishna's transcendental position fully
That material qualification determines one's ability to approach the Supreme Lord
That Krishna can be understood through mental speculation and scholarly analysis alone
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada warns that even demigods and great sages cannot understand Krishna through mental speculation. Scholarship is not the qualification to understand Krishna. The trap: thinking intellectual analysis reveals transcendental truth. Why this matters: The false path is approaching Krishna through mental gymnastics rather than devotional surrender. Real understanding comes from the Lord revealing Himself to surrendered devotees, not from speculative philosophy reaching conclusions about Him.

questions.prompt: In BG 10.3, what characterizes one who truly knows Krishna?
choices: Freedom from delusion with complete loving devotion
Hesitation between material and transcendental spiritual paths
Attachment to family duties and worldly material obligations
Philosophical uncertainty about the ultimate nature of reality
questions.feedback: One who knows Krishna as the unborn, beginningless Supreme Lord of all worlds becomes undeluded among men and freed from all sins. True knowledge brings complete liberation from material contamination. The contrast: ignorance binds through false identification; knowledge liberates through correct understanding of Krishna's supreme position and one's relationship to Him as eternal servant.

questions.prompt: What does BG 10.4-5 teach about Krishna's divine manifestations?
choices: All divine qualities originate from His nature
Consciousness arises from complex material arrangements
Divine qualities emerge from material nature itself
Spiritual powers develop through personal austerity
questions.feedback: Intelligence, knowledge, freedom from doubt, forgiveness, truthfulness, control of senses and mind, happiness, distress, birth, death, fear, fearlessness, nonviolence, equanimity, satisfaction, austerity, charity, fame, and infamy - all these various qualities originate from Krishna alone. The philosophical point: consciousness and its qualities are not material emergent properties but divine emanations from the Supreme Person. This refutes materialism at its foundation.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 10.8, what warning does Srila Prabhupada give about approaching Bhagavad-gita?
choices: That Krishna consciousness requires extensive academic credentials before beginning spiritual practice
That devotional sentiment should be balanced with intellectual skepticism very carefully
That scholarly analysis provides the best foundation for all spiritual understanding
That only fools consider Krishna an ordinary man and follow unauthorized commentaries
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada warns that only a fool would consider Krishna to be an ordinary man. One should avoid all unauthorized commentaries and interpretations on Bhagavad-gita. The psychological trap: thinking human analysis can judge the Supreme. Why this matters: The false path is approaching scripture through the filter of mundane commentators who don't accept Krishna's supreme position. Real advancement comes from learning Krishna consciousness through bona fide spiritual masters with references from Vedic literature, proceeding with determination and firmness.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 10.10, how does Srila Prabhupada distinguish buddhi-yoga from karma-yoga and jnana-yoga?
choices: Buddhi-yoga emphasizes intellectual understanding over devotional engagement and practical loving service to Krishna
Karma-yoga and jnana-yoga are superior because they require more personal effort and discipline
All three yogas lead equally to the same destination through different methods and approaches
Buddhi-yoga is complete Krishna consciousness through devotional service; karma-yoga pursues fruits; jnana-yoga pursues mental speculation
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that when one knows the goal is Krishna but is addicted to fruits of activities, it's karma-yoga. When one takes pleasure in mental speculation to understand Krishna, it's jnana-yoga. When one seeks Krishna completely in devotional service, it's buddhi-yoga - the complete yoga and highest perfectional stage. Why this matters: The false path is mixing methods or remaining in preliminary stages. Real buddhi-yoga means direct Krishna consciousness with love and devotion, not speculation or fruitive work.

questions.prompt: What does BG 10.11 teach about Krishna's compassion?
choices: He destroys ignorance with transcendental knowledge
He tests devotees with philosophical doubts
He remains neutral toward His devotees' struggles
He withdraws to cultivate their independence
questions.feedback: Out of compassion for those devoted to Him, dwelling in their hearts, Krishna destroys the darkness of ignorance with the shining lamp of knowledge. The divine grace: Krishna personally intervenes to remove obstacles. The principle: devotion attracts Krishna's mercy; mercy brings enlightenment. This is not mechanical cause-effect but personal relationship where the Supreme becomes subordinate to His devotee's welfare.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 10.13, what evidence does Srila Prabhupada cite about Krishna's supremacy?
choices: That great sages Narada, Asita, Devala, and Vyasa all confirm Krishna as Supreme Personality
That Krishna's supremacy is a matter of sectarian belief rather than Vedic truth
That philosophical speculation gradually leads sincere seekers to accept Krishna eventually
That various authorities hold different opinions about Krishna's position in reality
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada emphasizes that Arjuna accepts Krishna as the Supreme Personality, confirmed by great authorities like Narada, Asita, Devala, and Vyasa. The verse establishes that all great sages and demigods recognize Krishna's supremacy. Why this matters: The false path is thinking Krishna's position is debatable or a matter of opinion. Real understanding accepts the unanimous verdict of all authorized spiritual authorities throughout Vedic history that Krishna is the Supreme Absolute Truth.

questions.prompt: In BG 10.14, what does Krishna claim to know?
choices: Awareness limited by material conditioning and forms
Knowledge of physical phenomena and external forms
All divine manifestations and opulences completely
Partial understanding of the material manifestations
questions.feedback: Arjuna acknowledges that only Krishna Himself knows His own divine manifestations and opulences. Even great personalities cannot fully comprehend Krishna's unlimited nature. The epistemological point: finite intelligence cannot exhaust knowledge of the infinite. Yet Krishna mercifully reveals Himself to devotees, giving enough knowledge to develop relationship while maintaining His inconceivable transcendence. This is knowledge through revelation, not speculation.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 10.15, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about knowing Krishna fully?
choices: That scholarly study of Vedic texts provides complete knowledge of Krishna's nature
That only Krishna Himself can know His own unlimited opulences and manifestations completely
That advanced yogis through meditation can comprehend all of Krishna's divine qualities
That material intelligence when highly developed can grasp Krishna's transcendental position
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that Krishna alone knows His own opulences fully. Even great personalities cannot completely comprehend all His qualities and manifestations. The philosophical insight: the infinite cannot be fully grasped by the finite. Why this matters: The false path is thinking one can exhaust knowledge of Krishna through study or meditation. Real understanding accepts Krishna's inconceivable nature while progressively deepening relationship with Him through devotion, never claiming complete comprehension.

questions.prompt: According to BG 10.20, what is Krishna's declaration about His nature?
choices: I am the Self, beginning middle and end
I am confined by time and space
I appear and disappear within material cycles
I depend on the Supreme Brahman's support
questions.feedback: Krishna declares He is the Self seated in the hearts of all beings, the beginning, middle, and end of all existence. He is the Supersoul accompanying each individual soul. The ontological foundation: Krishna is simultaneously the source of all beings, their sustainer throughout existence, and their ultimate destination. Nothing exists before Him, nothing exists apart from Him, nothing exists after Him. All temporal and spatial categories dissolve in His transcendence.

questions.prompt: In BG 10.21, what example does Krishna give of His opulences in the material world?
choices: I withdraw my presence from natural phenomena
Matter operates entirely through independent laws
I am the sun among luminaries, Marici among Maruts, and the moon among stars
I exhibit few manifestations in visible creation
questions.feedback: Krishna begins describing His principal opulences: among Adityas He is Vishnu, among luminaries the radiant sun, among Maruts He is Marici, among stars the moon. The pedagogical method: Krishna uses familiar categories to help limited human consciousness grasp unlimited divine nature. Each manifestation represents Krishna's excellence in that category, teaching devotees to see His supremacy everywhere while recognizing all power flows from the source.

questions.prompt: What does BG 10.22 teach about the highest of Krishna's manifestations?
choices: All rests on Me like pearls on thread
I rank among the lesser transcendent principles
Divine manifestations function independently of each other
I am the Sama Veda among the Vedas, Indra among demigods, the mind among senses, and consciousness among living beings
questions.feedback: Among the Vedas Krishna is the Sama Veda, among demigods He is Indra, among senses the mind, among living beings consciousness. The hierarchical principle: even among exalted categories, Krishna is the most exalted. This systematic presentation shows Krishna's supremacy is not sectarian bias but metaphysical reality - He is the highest in every dimension of existence, the thread upon which all pearls of manifestation are strung.

questions.prompt: In BG 10.23, which opulences does Krishna list?
choices: He is the Sama Veda among the Vedas
He is Indra among demigods, the mind among senses, and consciousness among living beings
He is Vishnu among the Adityas, the sun among luminaries, Marici among Maruts, and the moon among stars
He is Shankara among Rudras, Kubera among Yakshas and Rakshasas, fire among Vasus, and Meru among mountains
questions.feedback: This verse lists one set of Krishna's vibhutis - He is the foremost in each category: Shankara among Rudras, Kubera among Yakshas and Rakshasas, fire among Vasus, and Meru among mountains. This illustrates Krishna's supremacy and the personal nature of the Absolute Truth.

questions.prompt: In BG 10.24, which opulences does Krishna identify with?
choices: I am the Sama Veda among the Vedas
I am Skanda among great generals and the ocean among bodies of water
I am the mind among the senses and consciousness among living beings
I am Shankara among Rudras, Kubera among Yakshas and Rakshasas, fire among Vasus, and Meru among mountains
questions.feedback: In BG 10.24, Krishna says He is Skanda (Kartikeya) among great generals and the ocean among bodies of water. This demonstrates that Krishna is the greatest in every category, and His manifestations are the most prominent and powerful.

questions.prompt: What does BG 10.25 teach about Krishna's opulences among sages, sacrifices, and mountains?
choices: He is Skanda among generals and the ocean among bodies of water
He is Bhrigu among sages, Om among vibrations, japa among sacrifices, and the Himalayas among mountains
He is the Sama Veda among the Vedas
He is Shankara among Rudras, Kubera among Yakshas and Rakshasas, fire among Vasus, and Meru among mountains
questions.feedback: In BG 10.25, Krishna says He is Bhrigu among sages, Om among vibrations, japa (chanting) among sacrifices, and the Himalayas among mountains. This illustrates Krishna's supremacy in spiritual, ritual, and natural categories.

questions.prompt: According to BG 10.26, which opulences does Krishna list?
choices: I am the banyan tree among trees, Bhrigu among sages, Citraratha among Gandharvas, and Kapila among perfected beings
I am the banyan tree among trees, Narada among sages, Citraratha among Gandharvas, and Skanda among perfected beings
I am the banyan tree among trees, Narada among sages, Skanda among Gandharvas, and Kapila among perfected beings
I am the banyan tree among trees, Narada among sages, Citraratha among Gandharvas, and Kapila among perfected beings
questions.feedback: In BG 10.26, Krishna says He is the banyan tree among trees, Narada among sages, Citraratha among Gandharvas, and Kapila among perfected beings. This verse highlights Krishna's supremacy as the greatest in every category, teaching us to see the divine source behind all excellence.

questions.prompt: In BG 10.27, which opulences does Krishna identify with?
choices: I am Ucchaihshravas among horses, Airavata among elephants, and the king among men
I am the banyan tree among trees, Narada among sages, Citraratha among Gandharvas, and Kapila among perfected beings
I am the thunderbolt among weapons, Kamadhenu among cows, Kandarpa among causes for procreation, and Vasuki among serpents
I am Skanda among great generals and the ocean among bodies of water
questions.feedback: In BG 10.27, Krishna says He is Ucchaihshravas among horses, Airavata among elephants, and the king among men. The point is not zoology or politics, but recognizing the Supreme as the peak excellence within each category, so the mind rises from impressive effects to the divine source behind them.

questions.prompt: What does BG 10.28 teach about Krishna's opulences among weapons, cows, procreation, and serpents?
choices: He is Vasudeva among the Vrishnis, Arjuna among the Pandavas, Vyasa among sages, and Ushana among great thinkers
He is Skanda among generals and the ocean among bodies of water
He is the thunderbolt among weapons, Kamadhenu among cows, Kandarpa among causes for procreation, and Vasuki among serpents
He is Bhrigu among sages, Om among vibrations, japa among sacrifices, and the Himalayas among mountains
questions.feedback: In BG 10.28, Krishna says He is the thunderbolt among weapons, Kamadhenu among cows, Kandarpa (Cupid) among causes for procreation, and Vasuki among serpents. This demonstrates Krishna's supremacy in both material and living categories.

questions.prompt: In BG 10.29, which opulences does Krishna list?
choices: He is Ananta among Nagas, Varuna among aquatic beings, Aryama among ancestors, and Yama among controllers
He is Bhrigu among sages, Om among vibrations, japa among sacrifices, and the Himalayas among mountains
He is Skanda among generals and the ocean among bodies of water
He is the thunderbolt among weapons, Kamadhenu among cows, Kandarpa among causes for procreation, and Vasuki among serpents
questions.feedback: In BG 10.29, Krishna says He is Ananta among Nagas, Varuna among aquatic beings, Aryama among ancestors, and Yama among controllers. This shows Krishna's supremacy in the categories of serpents, aquatic beings, ancestors, and controllers.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 10.39, what psychological trap does Srila Prabhupada warn against when appreciating Krishna's opulences?
choices: That appreciating divine manifestations is unnecessary for any devotional progress whatsoever
That material beauty and power have no connection to Krishna's supreme spiritual nature
That one may become attached to Krishna's material manifestations rather than Krishna Himself
That seeing Krishna's opulence everywhere automatically produces spiritual advancement without devotional practice
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that everything glorious, beautiful, or powerful is but a spark of Krishna's splendor. The trap: becoming fascinated with the manifestation rather than the source. Why this matters: The false path is stopping at appreciation of opulence without progressing to devotion to the opulent person. Real advancement means seeing all beauty and power as reminders to worship Krishna, using manifestations as stepping stones to the Supreme Person, not becoming attached to them as ends in themselves.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 10.42, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about the purpose of Krishna's opulence descriptions?
choices: That detailed knowledge of all manifestations is essential before devotional service can begin
That one fragment of Krishna sustains the entire universe; simply know this and engage in bhakti
That comprehensive study of all opulences gradually produces strong devotional attachment naturally
That intellectual understanding of Krishna's manifestations replaces need for surrender to Him
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains Krishna's essential message: what need is there for detailed knowledge of opulences? Know that with a single fragment of Myself I pervade and support this entire universe. The psychological insight: Krishna provides examples not for exhaustive catalog but to inspire devotion. Why this matters: The false path is endless intellectual accumulation about Krishna's manifestations. Real advancement means grasping the essential truth and proceeding to loving service, not remaining stuck in theoretical study.

questions.prompt: In BG 10.40, what point does Krishna make about His opulences?
choices: He is never absent from His devotees
His divine manifestations are endless; what He described is only a brief summary
Material suffering increases over lifetimes
Devotees must meditate on every opulence in detail
questions.feedback: In BG 10.40, Krishna states that His divine manifestations are endless and what He has described is only a brief summary. This teaches that the Supreme's opulences are unlimited, and the purpose of listing them is to inspire devotion, not to provide an exhaustive catalog.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 10.41, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about recognizing Krishna's opulence?
choices: That only spiritual phenomena should be considered manifestations of Krishna's nature
That any glorious or beautiful existence should be understood as Krishna's fragmental manifestation
That appreciating worldly beauty and power distracts from pure spiritual practice
That material opulence exists independently and has no connection to spiritual reality
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that anything extraordinarily opulent, beautiful, or glorious - whether in spiritual or material world - should be considered Krishna's opulence. The synthesis: the sacred and secular divide collapses when one sees Krishna's spark in all splendor. Why this matters: The false path is thinking matter is separate from spirit or that appreciation of beauty is material. Real Krishna consciousness sees all excellence as emanating from the Supreme, using material manifestations to remember and glorify the source rather than reject them as illusion.

questions.prompt: How does Chapter 10's extensive description of Krishna's opulences support the conclusion that bhakti-yoga surpasses all other paths?
choices: It shows that understanding manifestations intellectually produces complete liberation without devotion to Krishna
It proves that material opulence and spiritual advancement are completely unrelated in every way
It demonstrates that recognizing Krishna as source of all excellence naturally leads to worship and devotion
It establishes that studying manifestations is more important than direct Krishna consciousness and service
questions.feedback: The synthesis: Krishna reveals His opulences to inspire devotion, not for academic study. Seeing Krishna's excellence everywhere - from the sun's brilliance to the mind's consciousness - naturally produces wonder and worship. The chapter's pedagogical arc moves from establishing Krishna's supremacy through manifestations to the conclusion that one fragment of Him sustains everything. Why this matters: The false path is remaining in intellectual appreciation of opulence. Real understanding transforms knowledge into devotion, using perception of Krishna's glory throughout creation as constant reminder to engage in loving service to the Supreme Person who is the source of all magnificence.
